docs.snippet: Major League Soccer has lost some momentum in its inaugural playoff campaign. Having to juggle stadium availability and conflicts with World Cup qualifying matches, the league will start its semifinals tonight, eight days after the conclusion of the...
docs.lead_paragraph: Major League Soccer has lost some momentum in its inaugural playoff campaign. Having to juggle stadium availability and conflicts with World Cup qualifying matches, the league will start its semifinals tonight, eight days after the conclusion of the first round of the playoffs. The Tampa Bay Mutiny will visit D.C. United at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium in a game that will be shown live by ESPN, and the Kansas City Wiz will visit Los Angeles in the opening games of the two-of-three-game series. The winners will meet for the title Oct. 20 at Foxboro Stadium near Boston.
docs.abstract: Outlook for semifinal round of Major League Soccer playoffs (M)

headline.main: Belated Beginning for the M.L.S. Semifinal Round

docs.snippet: The Rev. Eugene Stockwell, a Methodist missionary and leader in international church work, died on Tuesday at his home in Atlanta. He was 73.    The cause was cancer, his wife, Margaret, said.

docs.snippet: Wymberley deRenne Coerr, an American career diplomat who was Ambassador to Uruguay and Ecuador in the 1960's, died on Oct. 5 in a hospital in Ajijic, Mexico, where he and his wife had rented a house for  three months. He was 83.     His death was...
docs.lead_paragraph: Wymberley deRenne Coerr, an American career diplomat who was Ambassador to Uruguay and Ecuador in the 1960's, died on Oct. 5 in a hospital in Ajijic, Mexico, where he and his wife had rented a house for three months. He was 83. His death was announced by his family last week. The cause was complications from Parkinson's disease, said his wife, Eleanor, of Clearwater, Fla.
docs.abstract: Wymberley deRenne Coerr, American career diplomat who was Ambassador to Uruguay and Ecuador in 1960's, dies at age 83 (S)

headline.main: Wymberly deR. Coerr, 83, Ex-U.S. Envoy to Uruguay and Ecuador

docs.snippet: Michael W. Moynihan, an advocate of free trade who served in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations, died on Tuesday at his home in Kitty Hawk, N.C. He was 68.    Mr. Moynihan, a brother of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, suffered from prostate...
docs.lead_paragraph: Michael W. Moynihan, an advocate of free trade who served in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations, died on Tuesday at his home in Kitty Hawk, N.C. He was 68. Mr. Moynihan, a brother of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, suffered from prostate cancer, although the cause of death has not been determined, his family said.
docs.abstract: Michael W Moynihan, advocate of free trade who served in Kennedy and Johnson Administrations, dies at age 68; he was brother of Sen Daniel Patrick Moynihan; photo (S)

headline.main: New Paris Import: Pondering the Big Questions at Cafes . . .

docs.snippet: Clinton Administration officials expect two major meetings in the next month to set the stage for a global agreement abolishing tariffs on computer and software products.    Such an Information Technology Agreement, or I.T.A., would liberalize some...
docs.lead_paragraph: Clinton Administration officials expect two major meetings in the next month to set the stage for a global agreement abolishing tariffs on computer and software products. Such an Information Technology Agreement, or I.T.A., would liberalize some $500 billion worth of computer and software exports annually -- roughly equivalent to world trade in agriculture -- among the United States, Canada, Europe, Japan and many other Asian and Latin American countries.
docs.abstract: Clinton Administration aides expect meetings of Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum and of World Trade Organization trade representatives to set stage for global accord abolishing tariffs on computer and software products; some experts see accord as key to breaking three-year logjam on multilateral trade agreements (M)

headline.main: Global Pact on Computers May Be Nearing

docs.snippet: When missionaries from the Unification Church came to South America in the early 1970's, they faced hostility in many countries, where the teachings of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, the church's spiritual leader, were considered sacrilege.    Critics of...
docs.lead_paragraph: When missionaries from the Unification Church came to South America in the early 1970's, they faced hostility in many countries, where the teachings of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, the church's spiritual leader, were considered sacrilege. Critics of the Unification Church, particularly the Catholic Church, which has long dominated religion in Latin America, denounced Mr. Moon's suggestions that he was the Messiah, as well as his recruiting and fund-raising tactics. Angry crowds stoned and sacked Unification churches.
docs.abstract: Unification Church has gained new respect in Latin America, where it has established strong foothold, access to rich and powerful and investments in real estate, hotels, banks, newspapers and other businesses valued at hundreds of millions of dollars; church officials say they have three million followers in region; just how far Unification Church has come in Latin America in last 20 years is evident when former Pres George Bush and dozens of current and former heads of state from region attend party in Buenos Aires on Nov 23 to inaugurate Spanish-language newspaper being published by media company with close ties to Rev Sun Myung Moon, church's spiritual leader (M)

headline.main: Unification Church Gains Respect in Latin America

docs.snippet: Amazon and Machu Picchu     Q.  We are a retired couple, looking for a relatively comfortable South American tour that includes Machu Picchu and the Amazon River. -- Dennis and Barbara Kallins, Atlanta      A.  While many tour companies offer trips...
docs.lead_paragraph: Amazon and Machu Picchu Q. We are a retired couple, looking for a relatively comfortable South American tour that includes Machu Picchu and the Amazon River. -- Dennis and Barbara Kallins, Atlanta A. While many tour companies offer trips to the Amazon region and to the Inca ruins of Machu Picchu, most do not combine the sites on the same itinerary. Depending on which part of the Amazon you want to see, the minimum distance from there to Machu Picchu is several hundred miles, and given the limitations on transportation for many segments of the river, the logistics can be considerable for a full group. It is more likely that you'll come across tours that include optional extensions to one or the other site.
docs.abstract: Question-and-answer column on travel; on Amazon and Machu Piccu, Mexico City hotels and Cotswolds antiques

docs.snippet: One day, Police Commissioner Howard Safir's plan to station a handful of officers in the Dominican Republic to track fugitives is alive. The next, it appears dead.    But if the fortunes of the initiative seem to shift as unpredictably as a Caribbean...
docs.lead_paragraph: One day, Police Commissioner Howard Safir's plan to station a handful of officers in the Dominican Republic to track fugitives is alive. The next, it appears dead. But if the fortunes of the initiative seem to shift as unpredictably as a Caribbean storm, it is because it has become intertwined in the mercurial politics of both New York and the Dominican Republic. And it is another sign that the relations between the United States and Latin America are always complex and difficult to navigate.
docs.abstract: News analysis discusses controvery in Dominican Republic over New York City Police Comr Howard Safir's proposal to set up handful of city officers in Dominican Republic to track drug fugitives (M)

headline.main: A Caribbean Storm for the Police

docs.snippet: With three weeks to go in 1996, more passengers have died in airline crashes this year than in any other, even though statistics show that air travel is becoming safer over time.    This year's high death toll is in part a result of the continuing...
docs.lead_paragraph: With three weeks to go in 1996, more passengers have died in airline crashes this year than in any other, even though statistics show that air travel is becoming safer over time. This year's high death toll is in part a result of the continuing rapid increase in the number of flights worldwide and, with it, the chances for an accident.
docs.abstract: More passengers died in airline crashes in 1996 than in any other year, but statistics still show air travel is becoming safer over time; death toll of 1,187 is partly result of continuing rapid increase in number of flights worldwide and, with it, chances for accidents; public's perceptions of increased risk, and some harsh new realities, have US Government officials and industry executives moving along number of fronts to improve aviation safety worldwide; focus is on archaic safety systems and often inadequately trained personnel in less developed regions, where many of crashes have been occurring; experts say regions with biggest rise in traffic have most problematic air traffic control system and personnel--such as Africa, Asia, Central America and South America, where bulk of deaths have occurred in most years; say if currrent accident rate remains steady and air travel continues to grow rapidly, passenger jet may crash as often as one per week by year 2010; since October '96, plane crash has occurred every two weeks on average; charts (M)

headline.main: Record Crash Death Toll in '96, But Statistically Travel Is Safer
headline.kicker: Air Safety Seeks to Keep Up With Growth
